value: meta entry for the BBCs internal phone directory web
Internal phone number for the Atos technology help desk (0345 305 0440 from an external phone)
Used to relay safety and security information about BBC Sites. Originally on Ceefax page 159, it is now a website.
the Operations team responsible for the continuity of the BBC's online services. ‚Äú247‚Äù and ‚Äú24/7‚Äù are commonly used Slack stalkwords
Emergency services phone number for use on a BBC site. (020 7765 1666 from an external phone)
the BBC‚Äôs training department, which provides courses in everything from software engineering to how to safely do journalism in the middle of a war zone
Audience Content Experiences, a Software Engineering org unit in the Product Group which maps to News & Sport, Children‚Äôs & Education, and some other things in other disciplines. MAP is a sibling.
A colour encoding system used in grading software.  Standardised by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences
Audience-facing service which allows viewers to synchronise subscriptions to  Radio or TV programmes across multiple devices (different from BBC Login, below) see also IDCTA
Architecture Decision Record, which documents a technical architecture decision and its rationale.
Automated Dialogue Replacement
Not to be confused with Agile Methodology or Agile software development, the term used on BBC People systems to signify a person is Hybrid Working. See also Flexible-first.
Gaelic for ‚ÄúScotland‚Äù
webpages rendered as Accelerated Mobile Pages, in the BBC by Simorgh, to produce lightweight pages that can be heavily cached by the likes of Google\n
broadly, ‚Äúserver room‚Äù, but as likely to contain broadcast equipment as servers
Available Programmes Publication Workflow
Applied Research Area: a set of groups within R&D.

The in-house weekly magazine of the BBC named after the character Ariel from Shakespeare‚Äôs The Tempest who is depicted on the 1932 statue on the facade of the BBC's Old Broadcasting House. Now an email newsletter and intranet site app.

acronym: Arqiva ‚Äî the monopoly provider of terrestrial transmission services in the UK: is responsible for broadcasting the BBC and almost all other broadcasters‚Äô services on analogue radio (FM, AM), digital radio (DAB), and digital terrestrial television (DTT / Freeview). Formed ultimately from the sale of the independent transmission networks in 1990 and the BBC‚Äôs transmission network in 1997. One of the largest suppliers to the BBC.

value: commonly-used contraction of the AMWA AS-11 UK DPP HD file format used to deliver television programmes to UK broadcasters in a standardised way, so that they ‚Äújust work‚Äù as would you expect if you played a video cassette. The DPP was formed to address this problem after a cassette shortage caused by the Japanese tsunami. Hugely successful but limited for applications such object-based media, so is hoped will be replaced by IMF.

Genericised/eroded trademark (from Aston Broadcast Systems) referring to on-screen graphic overlays (e.g. headlines, guests‚Äô names, a clock) placed in the title-safe ‚Äúlower third‚Äù area of the screen. Also called a ‚Äúlower third‚Äù or a ‚ÄúChyron‚Äù (U.S.). Notes;\n
A web-based game loader for embedding games onto BBC pages (formerly known as CAGE).
Company that provides IT services to the BBC
Nickname for the BBC (increasingly archaic)
Advertising supported VOD services (see also SVOD
Amazon Web Services, cloud hosting platform used by many BBC online services
Microsoft‚Äôs cloud hosting platform used by a few BBC services
BBC Activity Gateway
BBC Analytics Pipeline
‚Äòfiller‚Äô content broadcast when a channel is off-air (e.g. overnight on CBeebies)
The British Broadcasting Corporation

Studios Product in development, a tri-media (read, watch, listen) international replacement for the current bbc.com website (and associated mobile Apps) presenting news, documentaries and audio (podcasts) to the international (ex-UK) audience
Broadcast Centre

Broadcast & End-User Technology, part of the Technology Group. Responsible for the design and delivery of the technology required for content and programme making and channel assembly, and the common IT systems used across the organisation

Broadcasting House in London, the BBC‚Äôs principal office. Sometimes LBH to distinguish it from other cities‚Äô Broadcasting Houses. Made up of OBH and NBH (Old and New) See also: W1A, below.  Not to be confused with the many smaller Broadcasting Houses across the country.\n
BBC Internet Distribution Infrastructure

acronym: Big Red Button 3 (BRB3) ‚Äì Content management system of the international (ex-UK) BBC.com homepage. Not to be confused with Red Button TV text services.

value: A family of apps (from the Video & Graphics Tools
To replace potentially offensive, missing, or problematic audio with recorded birdsong.

Part of the Children‚Äôs & Education offering, BBC Bitesize is a study resource for learners aged 3 to 16+. Though primarily a website and app, educational programming is also produced and broadcast, most notably ‚ÄúBitesize Daily‚Äù during the COVID-19 pandemic. See also: What is Bitesize?
the standard BBC ‚Äòblocks‚Äô logo\n
a BBC building at Media City in Salford, until around March 2024
an international subscription video on-demand (SVOD) service, owned by ITV in the UK, but shared between ITV and BBC Studios in other countries.
ITU-R BT.2100 is the standard used for UHDTV
ITU-R BT.709 is the standard used for HDTV
Channel logo displayed on TV or streaming service. See also: DOG

Bush House on Aldwych, London.  For decades home to the BBC World Service, and also offices in the early days of the BBC website and interactive TV services.  Sometimes referred to as BVSH due to the stylised building name above the main entrance doors.
‚ÄúBroadcast‚Äù video on demand: video-on-demand free at point of use as in ITVX, iPlayer.  Compare SVOD
Certificate Authority, the BBC has several

A grid of audio players containing jingles, station identifications, stings, and music. Originally a \"cart\" was a cartridge containing a magnetic tape. Now cart walls are computerised and touch-screen. See also Sting.

An open source playout server/graphics engine originated at Swedish TV (SVT).  Can take live and file-based inputs, do dynamic overlays based on HTML5 and produce an SDI output using off the shelf hardware.
Internal tool for making clips. (part of Media Tools)
see Obit
Children‚Äôs BBC; a TV channel and website for 6-13 year olds.
A discontinued ‚Äòsocial‚Äô media app for under 13s.  Closed due to it being too popular and requiring large amounts of expensive content moderation. (YouTube Video of App)
A TV channel, website and set of apps for under 6s (and their grown ups). The name is a diminutive form of CBBC, see above.
Centralised Coding & Mux (Multiplexing).
Chief Customer Officer
the group of divisions that report up to the CCO, responsible for describing, counting, and marketing to our customers, who are also sometimes called our audience.

Content Delivery Network, a content caching service that stores and serves content (web pages, data, or chunks of AV media) closer to the end user than the  content origin. The BBC uses third-party CDNs such as Akamai, Cloudfront, Fastly for various purposes and also runs its own
Now defunct, the BBCs much loved teletext service for analogue TV sets

often abbreviated as ‚Äúcert‚Äù. A digital file containing (usually) encrypted information. In BBC contexts, usually refers to a user certificate, often known by its older name of ‚Äúdev cert‚Äù, which can uniquely identify a specific user and authorise them to perform certain tasks. They are issued through the EJBCA system.
BBC-wide project started in 2021 to devise and apply refreshed branding/look-and-feel using consistent colours, shapes, animations, and font. See also: GEL, Reith fonts.

acronym: Channels & Product Excellence -(aka CPX, formerly known as Core Services) an organisational unit in Product Group who manage WebCore amongst other services such as Orbit, Belfrage, Fabl, WebCore Design System, WebCore Framework and WebCore Platform

value: Collective term for CBBC and CBeebies brands (including TV channels, websites, apps, and CBeebies Radio)

an organisational unit in Product Group which delivers audience-facing digital products for children (e.g. CBBC) and parents (e.g. CBeebies, Tiny Happy People), students (e.g. Bitesize) and educators (e.g. Teach), etc.\n
Chief Information Security Officer
BBC wide internal wiki
BBC Content
Chief Operating Officer
A sandbox environment for playing with SMP configurations. Available at https://cookbook.tools.bbc.co.uk/
Chief Operating Officer Group
the six highest-priority digital service brands: News, Sport, Weather, iPlayer, Sounds, Bitesize; each has a service identifier

A project from the Media Services Site Reliability Engineering team to build future-facing tooling supporting Release Engineering to provide continuous integration and delivery. At the moment it comprises of a few tools including Pipeline Creator which automates the creation of AWS CodePipeline pipelines to build and deploy projects from GitHub to Cosmos etc and is intended as a replacement for Jenkins etc.
an art deco, oak-panelled room in OBH, the setting for many major formal BBC meetings and events over the years
Chief Product Officer
Content Production Workflows
Colour Separation Overlay
either\n
Chief Technology Officer
word used by management to refer to a member of our audiences
Welsh for ‚ÄúWales‚Äù

David Manning, popular former internal comms person, who often organises and chairs comms sessions. On 2022-09-15, David greatly upset many #global-random participants by announcing that he was leaving BBC.\n

The Department for Digital, Culture, Media and (for some reason also) Sport. The UK government department ultimately responsible for setting the legal framework for media organisations in the UK, including the BBC.
Digital Distribution, part of the Technology Group currently headed by Richard Cooper.
Design Delivery Review
Design + Engineering, the former BBC staff group that split to become Product Group and Technology Group in 2021.
Abbreviation of Director General
the company which is responsible for Freeview and (since a merger in 2021) also for Freesat. The BBC is a shareholder. Now called Everyone TV (as of early 2023)
the top boss, equivalent of a CEO, in the BBC. Since September 2020, Tim Davie. See also: Director-General of the BBC. Not to be confused with the BBC CEOs that exist.

Literally ‚Äúcutting out the middle person‚Äù; in the context of broadcasting, this ought to refer to removing the intermediaries such as TV manufacturers‚Äô platforms and user interfaces and having the viewer connected directly to the broadcaster. However, used within the BBC to mean the exact opposite.
Product Group‚Äôs definition of work categories: Deprecated, Accelerate, Validate, Incubate, Sustain. See https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/PDG/DAVIS

Disability Services Assessment. Sometimes used to describe equipment assigned from an assessment e.g. DSA Chair, a chair assigned to an individual to meet their required adjustments. See https://staff.bbc.com/gateway/hr/for-my-team/how-do-i/arrange-an-access-and-disability-services-assessment/
You might be best doing your own research on this one, but it does still come up in conversation, even though it‚Äôs better if we Don‚Äôt Mention It
a Windows-based platform which for hosting, managing and moderating audience comments on BBC content. Originally hosted h2g2. DNA is a TLA for Douglas Noel Adams. Decommissioned April 2023.
Digital Onscreen Graphic

acronym: Dogging- the application of a DOG to a video. \n![An example of double dogging](https://paper-attachments.dropboxusercontent.com/s_1F19CB939E45A445A821DF56ED260F1D3B443BE267447A98BDE74942C19C44E8_1667741419588_Screenshot+from+2022-11-06+13-22-11.png)

value: Where multiple DOGs are drawn onto the same video, common on Simulcast event streams üëâ
A ruler of Venice. Wow. Such Pope.
Colloquial term for the Dockyard pub, Dock House, Media City
Someone in the pub fell over
2nd Floor of Dock House in Media City, home of Interactive TV (teams working on TV apps for iPlayer, Sounds and RedButton), SMP Mobile, and other mobile teams
4th floor of Dock House in Media City, Home of many important things that are too secret to be signposted in the Dock House lobby.
5th floor of Dock House in Media City, Northern home of BBC Research & Development

external company which operates the studios and facilities in Media City, provider of some services to the BBC. Named for its location next to dock number 9 (and roughly where the putative dock number 10 would have been), not because it‚Äôs on the 10th floor of Dock House.
a BBC building at Media City.
the, a pub/bar in Media City frequented by BBC Staff
Duty Operations Manager

The Digital Production Partnership. Originally a consortium of UK broadcasters including the BBC, formed to work towards a standardised file-based SD and HD TV programme delivery mechanism to replace video cassettes. Now an independent company, its focus has shifted.
The Digital TV Group. An industry body which writes the technical standards for terrestrial broadcasting in the UK (published as ‚ÄúThe DBook‚Äù).
Down The Line

Digital Terrestrial Television. TV that comes from a transmitting station equipped with a tall tower, or on top of a big hill, or sometimes both (as opposed to cable or satellite). Freeview is the public-facing name for this. Operated by Digital UK.
Digital Video Broadcasting, a Standards Body.

New BBC recording and rehearsal studios in the new ‚Äúcultural quarter‚Äù of London‚Äôs Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park. To be a location of live and recorded music sessions for Radio 1, 6 Music, Radio 2, and Radio 3 and home to the BBC Concert Orchestra, BBC Proms, and BBC Radio 3 New Generation Artists.

A content management system that powers the Music Events front-end and used to manage Music Events such as Glastonbury and 6Music Festival. Named after the Eavis family, hosts and organisers of the Glastonbury Festival.

European Broadcasting Union.  A members organisation of public service media organisations within the European Broadcasting Area (A rectangle that contains all European countries + some African and Asian countries).  Runs the Eurovision and Euroradio networks,  News exchange and undertakes technical harmonisation, including occasional singing competitions.  Based in Geneva. The BBC is a member.\n
Energy Centre

a library for mobile apps, media players, integrated devices, and (some) websites, which provides a relatively simple and unified way for BBC products to collect user activity events for analytics and regulatory purposes
An internal certificate authority (CA) used by BBC developers (disambiguation from Greenhouse and ‚Äúdev cert‚Äù?)

The Elstree Centre in Borehamwood is a large studio complex which includes the external set for EastEnders and Holby City. Was the location for training via BBC Academy. Elstree Studios nearby is an independent film studio, but some BBC productions use space there.
Since 1997 has been the primary BBC‚Äôs Image library system http://elvis.national.core.bbc.co.uk/ and https://elvis.tools.bbc.co.uk/
A gagging order preventing the early release of information when sharing it with third parties. Used in the BBC for pre-transmission content.
Electronic Programme Guide
Extended TLA, to describe acronyms of more than three letters.
European Telecommunications Standards Institute (also known as The European Tourism and Sightseeing Institute owing to the location of its headquarters in France‚Äôs C√¥te d‚ÄôAzur).
Everyone TV; the company responsible for Freeview and Freesat, and were previously called Digital UK. Planning a new product called Freely, which is the ‚Äònext gen‚Äô Freeview.
The Executive Committee of senior management (see bottom of doc for list of members)
markets/audiences which are external to the UK. See BBCX.

The CDN company used by the BBC for site/page delivery of www.bbc.com and www.bbc.co.uk, and also the zone apexes. Use varies between different geographies. See https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ta/Run+book+for+Fastly
cute, cuddly, not-at-all-scary characters who appear on some of the BBC website‚Äôs error pages; named in reference to the fire clown, who was much less relaxing.
see Fire-clangers
An early version of a flexible working strategy in response to the Covid-19 pandemic, now deprecated in favour of Hybrid Working.

Future Media & Technology.  Former BBC organisational unit, previously New Media & Technology, subsequently split into BBC Future Media (which was later renamed BBC Digital), and separately BBC Technology, Distribution, and Archives (which was later renamed BBC Engineering), before they were recombined into BBC Design & Engineering, which was then rebranded as BBC Design + Engineering, before being split into the current BBC Technology Group and BBC Product Group.
the BBC‚Äôs in-house managed deployment stack for online applications, now largely replaced by cloud services such as AWS.
Formerly NGP or Next Generation Platform. A UK PSB wide initiative to provide an IPTV based linear broadcasting service for UK audiences, due to replace Freesat and Freeview some time around 2030.
Fixed-Term Contract, as opposed to permanent employment
See Mice
A collection of applications with varying levels of functionality combined to form a rudimentary intranet site.
a Media Services API used to upload digital content to online publication systems
Google Cloud Platform, cloud hosting platform used by some BBC online services.
Global Experience Language, a design language/visual style guide intended to be used throughout the BBC‚Äôs output (previous versions were called GVL, Global Visual Language).
An in-house game framework built around the Phaser JavaScript game engine. See also Ivor.

acronym: BBC Global News (formerly Global News Ltd, GNL)
value: a commercial company now part of BBC Studios, quasi-successor to BBC Worldwide; not to be confused with World Service.
A Slack channel and assumed to be the back-channel for all-hands meetings although it actually is the meeting. Definitely a hive-mind.
Group of pictures, a unitary group of successive frames coded together within a digital video, usually 3.84 seconds long for Video Factory (iPlayer) content

A monitor that has been assessed to meet the required parameters set out in EBU Tech.3320 when measured in accordance with EBU Tech.3325.  Grade 1 monitors are used for picture quality assessment, Grade 2 for signal monitoring and Grade 3 for in vision monitors which require accurate colorimetry.
pre-recorded sound.
\n
strictly speaking (not that one), a psychological state that‚Äôs open to personal growth, improving oneself; less strictly, focussing on improving organisational performance
Global Traffic Management
Former DG of the BBC (2013
A scheduling technique in which a new programme is scheduled between two very popular programmes to gain a larger audience.
Hybrid Broadcast Broadband TV. System used to deliver interactive ‚ÄúRed Button‚Äù applications on TV, alongside the older MHEG language
High Dynamic Range, a larger range of brightness levels than traditional television signals offer, allowing more vibrant pictures especially when they contain highlights.

Hybrid Log-Gamma scene-referred HDR format standardised by BBC and NHK in ITU-R BT.2100. The scheme enables HDR signals to be transmitted over traditional broadcast chains, and produces an acceptable results on legacy standard dynamic range displays.
Progressive Web App with a ‚Äúwrapper‚Äù such as Cordova or Capacitor to enable it to be placed on the mobile app stores
A strategy combining working from home and working from a BBC office in an as-yet unspecified ratio.  See also Flexible-first.
International Broadcasting Convention, held every year in Amsterdam
iPlayer Business Layer (an API)
a system used to edit programme metadata
The entry point to BBC Account from integrating products. Offers a token refresh mechanism and UI components (prompting the user to sign in or register).
A sting used between or during TV and radio programmes to identify the channel or station. Often accompanied by scheduling information. Further info
Internet Engineering Task Force, a working group to develop technical standards for the internet, the BBC has members on some of its boards
The BBCs UK only BVoD service, see VoD

Interoperable Master Format, a framework for managing and delivering media assets like TV programmes in an efficient and extensible way. Used for delivery of UHD programmes to iPlayer. Hoped this will replace AS-11 for HD delivery too. A couple of clear advantages:\n
Information Security or the people who help us to stop getting hacked
Precursor to BBC Sounds.
Internet protocol television, industry term for watching TV via internet protocol, rather than satellite or ‚Äústicks on hills‚Äù terrestrial. Due to be used by Freely\n
Internet Relay Chat, real-time text chat protocol from the 80s, largely replaced by Slack and Teams but some parts of the BBC still use it

A live feed that is provided to be intercut with a programme feed or to be recorded and added in post.  Many arguments over its origin, Isochronous seems to be favoured. Iso recordings are often originated from an auxiliary feed from a TV studio vision mixer, a direct feed from an outside source in a TV studio, or a direct feed of one of the TV studio cameras.

The International Organisation for Standardization. A members organisation of national standards bodies, based in Geneva.  (ISO isn‚Äôt an abbreviation, it‚Äôs Greek for equal and is, fittingly, the same in every language).
Interactive Technical Advice and Contracts Unit
IT Coordinator, A nebulous role in need of a better definition within this document
Independent Television News, a production company that produces the news output under various brands, including for Channel 4 and ITV
The International Telecommunication Union, a UN agency that standardises Radio and Television Broadcasting and Telecommunication.  Based in Geneva.
either:\n
A game engine built around PixiJS for making games for younger audiences. Named after Ivor the Engine from the children‚Äôs TV show. See also Genie.\n    JAM
BBC wide issue ticketing and tracking software
Joiners/Movers/Leavers. A shorthand for the processes used to grant and remove access to systems to and from people who are joining, leaving, or moving role. May once also have been an actual system?
Shorthand for a journalist or reporter
an in-house developed video media asset management system used in News.
A 2008 attempt by the BBC, ITV, and C4 to produce a BritBox-style VOD service. The project was blocked by the Competition Commission at the time, which ruffles feathers to this day
Kerris Bright, the Chief Customer Officer (CCO)

Colloquial term for The Filling Station, the small snack/food booth which was based in TVC in White City. https://twitter.com/killingstation Later renamed ‚ÄúFuel Stop‚Äù and colloquially renamed ‚ÄúGruel Stop‚Äù. See also Spews Cafe.
London Broadcasting House in London‚Äîthe new name for OBH, NBH, and Peel Wing; see BH and W1.\n

acronym: LCN ‚Äî logical channel number; an entry in an EPG

value: The BBC Linked Data Platform, once the future, now deprecated.
Leigh Tavaziva, the Chief Operating Officer (COO) head of Operating Group.

the UK spelling of the term, which is used in our means of funding: ‚Äúlicence fee‚Äù or ‚ÄúTV licence‚Äù. Frequently misspelled due to the prevalence of its use in software. Note that the verb ‚Äúto license‚Äù is not spelled with a ‚Äòc‚Äô
One of the few remaining BBC buildings in W12. Occupied by R&D and DD personnel. Sometimes known as R&D South Lab
a TV or Radio station that is broadcast (or otherwise distributed), with the programme choice and ordering decided by someone other than the listener/viewer
An area in the Radio 1 / 1Xtra studios in NBH large enough for a band in which live music and video is recorded and streamed for radio, Sounds and iPlayer.
Staff-facing service which controls access to apps and services (different from BBC Account, above)
see Aston
a self-service learning resource for agile practice
A complex of seven BBC sound studios in Maida Vale, west London. Also home of the BBC Symphony Orchestra and location for John Peel Sessions recordings between 1967 and 2004.
a building in central Birmingham, home to BBC Birmingham and BBC Midlands, as well as other offices and shops
org unit
\n

for historical legal & liability reasons, the publisher of mobile apps like iPlayer/Sounds/Sport/News in the UK. A wholly owned subsidiary of BBC UK. https://find-and-update.company-information.service.gov.uk/company/07100235/officers

(formerly ‚ÄúMediaCityUK‚Äù) Location of the BBC‚Äôs offices in Salford, Greater Manchester. The BBC‚Äôs buildings here are Bridge House (until 2024), Dock House and Quay House. The Dockyard pub and dock10 studios adjoin Dock House.
a team within Digital Distribution (DD) that provides media transcoding and playback services for BBC Public Service and non-UK versions of Britbox.
Major Incident. When something breaks and it impacts multiple services (see P1, P2, P3, P4)
BBC buildings famously have had mouse infestations in the past. Some of these mice have created their own Twitter accounts:\n
The short straw of real-time chat services used in the BBC. Oh god no the pain!
shared presentation and business logic layer for News, Sport, and other products, currently in maintenance mode and set to be deprecated; named after Tony Hart‚Äôs mascot
Mandatory Sign In (for our users when they visit BBC websites or use our apps or sites)
Amazon Managed Streaming for Apache Kafka
‚ÄúMedia Player View‚Äù and API designed to present Clip and Episode information needed to play it out on BBC website and apps (via SMP). It is backed by the Clips API and Nitro.
Minimum Viable Product
see Nations and Regions
Scottish Gaelic word for News.  Brand name of the online news service in Scottish Gaelic.
New Broadcasting House is the newest (opened 2012) part of London‚Äôs Broadcasting House. Next to Old Broadcasting House but is actually Broadcasting House. See also: BH, W1A.
2022 project to update news sets ‚Äî named after a civil war battle (naturally)
the BBC‚Äôs output catering to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland; sometimes(?) includes content catering to England.  Also a BBC organisational Division
the BBC‚Äôs output catering to local audiences (TV, Radio, and Online) around the UK (plus the Channel Islands and Isle of Man). Also a former Organisational construct.
Northern Coding Operation. See CCM

Non Disclosure Agreement, a legally binding agreement, used to control the disemmination and usage of sensitive information when releasing it to third parties. Used by TV manufacturers, AWS architects, and other service providers to the BBC. The BBC‚Äôs legal team also issues our own NDAs, which must be signed by third-party developers before they are permitted access to our systems. Can be used as a form of embargo
Network Device Interface
organisational unit renamed to Future Media once ‚ÄúNew Media‚Äù no longer seemed new enough

Small restaurant in the basement of NBH serving a selection of cold and hot drinks, snacks, and meals such as Stuffed Aborigine, stolen cakes https://twitter.com/thisismds/status/805849264593272832, and always with the secret ingredient; sulphur https://twitter.com/betandr/status/578200113908178945.
See Freely
News programme on the BBC Scotland TV channel, broadcast at 9pm or 7pm. See also The Six and The Ten.

an API which provides metadata about TV, radio, and on demand programmes. Used internally within the BBC to serve data from PIPs to applications such as iPlayer and Sounds. Nitro is currently (2024) in the process of being deprecated.
Native Mobile Application (e.g ‚Äúthe iPlayer app is an NMA‚Äù)
News on iPlayer
BBC R&D‚Äôs presence in Media City
Outside Broadcast, a broadcast originating from outside of a studio.
Old Broadcasting House in London; see BH
Object-Based Media. We aren‚Äôt entirely sure what this is yet, but R&D are looking into it

a way of quickly replacing all content on the website with suitable coverage, which was used when Queen Elizabeth died. It will be used again when the king dies (or any other person defined as ‚ÄúCategory One‚Äù).
the Office of Communications, the independent regulator for the communications industry, which has the legal power to hold the BBC (and other media organisations) to account
Journo speak for ‚ÄúWe never had this conversation‚Äù
See Reith, network location
Abbreviation of ‚ÄúThe One O‚ÄôClock News‚Äù, a daily news programme broadcast at 1pm (usually, on weekdays) on the BBC One TV channel; not to be confused with The One Show
‚ÄúWe are one BBC. Great things happen when we work together‚Äù, see: this document
staff who report (directly or indirectly) to COO.

In BBC Sport, One Page Per Match. This (in the outgoing paradigm) refers to a non-live match page (example), which is a sub-type of CPS STY (story).  In the incoming paradigm an OPPM will be a live page powered by Tipo.

Software that provides common functions on some parts of the BBC website, notably the global navigation, some client-side APIs, and other stuffs like Analytics which product teams can‚Äôt all know about in detail. Amalgamates modules owned by various teams with domain knowledge; it‚Äôs included on many pages owned by other teams. All the parts can update autonomously. Replaced ORB (One Response Barlesque) circa 2018, which replaced Barlesque, which replaced Barley‚Ä¶ Consult #help-orbit on Slack. Not used by WebCore. Not to be confused with Obit.
Short hand for the organisation, the BBC
The audience facing content we produce across various mediums and platforms
When something breaks and impacts services, but not as bad as an MI. P1 is the most important priority after MI; P4 is the least important. Approximately:\n
Programme as Broadcast

Programme as Completed form. Production complete a PasC for each programme/episode to record the elements in the programme, contract details, rights, etc. such as for contributors (actors, musicians etc.), copyright material (scripts, poems etc.), film & videotape (clips, newly shot stuff, etc.)

(former?) location of the BBC Archives in West London. A running joke: during one all-staff meeting, someone anonymously asked about Perivale repeatedly. Also known as PERIVALE. See also Staring Tortoise.
see Staring Tortoise
Peter O‚ÄôKane, the Chief Technology Officer (CTO) head of Technology Group, often referenced as POK, PoK or Po‚ÄôK.\n

BBC Programme Identifier. Programmes get multiple IDs depending on who and what is processing them; the PID is a BBC-internal identifier that is used to uniquely identify specific programme metadata. PIDs sometimes get exposed to the audience in URLs for iPlayer, Sounds and other BBC sites and applications. (See also, PIPs)
BBC BH Newcastle.  https://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/18983269.bbc-radio-newcastles-50th-anniversary-marked/

a database and API for programme & availability metadata, and possibly one of the oldest systems still in use at the BBC. Data from PIPs makes it way via various routes to iPlayer, Sounds, and online/set-top-box EPGs along with various other systems. (See also, PID, Nitro, APPW & SPW.)

Post-Incident Review. Following a serious systems outage there is a no-blame review process to identify what caused the failure and how processes can be improved to reduce the possibility of it recurring
Product Group Leadership Team, led by the CPO
Programme Making and Special Events, the spectrum allocation used in studios, at OBs, at major sporting and cultural venues etc.  for Radio Mics, Camera Links, Talkback‚Ä¶.
see Peter.

An agreement to share footage, currently the BBC shares with Sky, GB News and ITN, as a way to reduce the number of cameras in a room and the amount of staff travelling to a location.  Often used for events such as a Politician landing at an airport or arrivals at Downing Street.
Pacific Quay, the BBC‚Äôs main site in Glasgow
staff who report (directly or indirectly) to the CPO

Public Service Broadcaster/Broadcasting. The legal requirement for certain TV companies in the UK (including, but not limited to, the BBC) to produce programmes that are intended for the public good rather than purely to serve commercial interests.
those bits of the BBC that are funded by the TV Licence, as opposed to commercial funding as with BBC Studios.  In some contexts used to exclude World Service, even where that is Licence Fee funded.
Progressive Web App

Abbreviation of ‚ÄúThe Six O‚ÄôClock News‚Äù, a major daily news programme broadcast at 6pm (usually, on weekdays) on the BBC One TV channel. See also The Ten.

Slack emoji and former Slack app for discouraging the use of '@here' in shared channels: Like most large orgs, Slack seeped into the BBC unplanned as individual teams created their own free tier workspaces for internal chatter.  Once the number of workspaces became a bit ridiculous, the AppAdmin team adopted and provided Slack officially, creating the ‚Äúenterprise grid‚Äù which links all individual Slack workspaces together behind BBC login.  This allowed for the creation of cross-workspace ‚Äúglobal channels‚Äù.  New users, unaware of the four digits worth of employees they could now directly ping, sometimes used '@here' or '@channel' in these global spaces, much to the merriment of all.  Despite global-random being created with the explicit instruction that ‚ÄúYou can all go and taunt BBC Slack Police to your heart‚Äôs content in there‚Äù, the account has since ceased operation.\n![BBC slack Police enforcing the rule of law onto an unsuspecting employee, followed be a carnival of emoji](https://paper-attachments.dropboxusercontent.com/s_863607DE1CC204D4A0D805A24C61E40C6EB5253C9755B4A2BBAD95EE1C87D62B_1697471732341_image.png)

Security Operations Centre. A function of Infosec, which is staffed 24/7. They monitor the BBC‚Äôs infrastructure for security threats and take action when required. Based in Dock House at Media City and contactable via information.security@bbc.co.uk.

‚ÄúBBC Sounds. Music. Radio. Podcasts.‚Äù The BBC‚Äôs audio product, making music, live and on-demand (catchup) radio and podcasts available to the audience via its website, mobile apps, smart tv app, smart speakers, etc. Launched in 2018.

Single Sign-On. A service that allows users to log in to several systems through one route with one set of credentials. BBC Login provides this function for the BBC.

refers to multiple things:\n
Weekly Active Accounts: accounts/profiles using BBC Online in a given week, accessing from a location within the UK (or its crown dependencies) OR have an account registered in the UK.
Weekly Active Users: accounts/profiles using BBC Online in a given week, accessing from a location within the UK (or its crown dependencies).
content on iPlayer thats live but not shown on a linear channel at the same time (simulcast) e.g. during live events such as Glastonbury, Olympics.

Current web platform being used / migrated to by some parts of the BBC website, including News, Sport, Homepage, but not including iPlayer, Sounds, World Service (which uses Simorgh). WebCore is run and supported by Channels & Product Excellence (sometimes referred to as CPX or ChannelsPX)

An area of West London and home to various current and former BBC buildings near Shepherd‚Äôs Bush including TVC, Broadcast Centre, Media Village, White City One, Media Centre, Energy Centre, and The Lighthouse. Aka W12.

Formerly Western House, a building on Great Portland Street and the home of BBC Radio 2, BBC Radio 6 Music (for some shows, others are in Dock House), and contains a BBC Club and gym. Named for former BBC presenter Terry Wogan. It was announced around 3rd Nov 2022 that the BBC would be vacating Wogan House by the end of 2023.

public-service worldwide news, part-funded by the UK government; not to be confused with BBC Global News. Frequently abbreviated WS.
was merged into BBC Studios in 2018

World Radio Conference. An ITU meeting where spectrum allocation is agreed. Affects availability for DTT, DSAT, PMSE, 3G, 4G, 5G and plenty other acronyms and abbreviations. Happens every 10 years or so, next one is in 2027.
Means of accessing AWS accounts protected by BBC developer certificates.
code for the off-site ‚Äúmeeting space‚Äù near New Broadcasting House, known by the public as the Yorkshire Grey pub.

the cloud security company behind the products used by staff to access the Reith intranet from public internet connections. Common source of anger and frustration. The product which staff will be aware of on their computers is called Zscaler Private Access, or ZPA for short. It operates in a similar way to a VPN. It works with DNS records and not IP addresses, which breaks some IP protocols. Another product from Zscaler is ZIA
